title: Irish Open Data Reuse Exemplars
segmentation: OK, thank you very much conscious that I'm the last or next to last speaker of the day, so I don't want to be keeping you all from dinner, so I'll I'll go through this quickly.
I'm just going to give a quick run through of what's happened with publishing open date in Ireland and how the data has been reused.
So first of all, let's give you background of finger off.
This is a finger.
Coast Finger is in North County Dublin.
If you flew into Dublin airport you would have come through finger also basically North of.
And City third largest local area local authority area by population in the country.
Youngest profile in the country fast.
Growing in the country, our population would have grown from around 160 seven 1273 thousand in the 15 year period up to 2011.
So to cope with that level of growth and providing services to the citizens of finger, we relied very heavily on data on on using data, particularly census type data for service planning and that.
Let us into open data.
Our experience with data and the desire and the initiative to start publishing our data.
That data held by the local authority as open data and this would have happened two years ago.
We would have published finger open data data dot finger dot IE.
It's been through three iterations in that time period and is now over 170 datasets on the site.
In 12 different categories, everything from demographics to environment.

You can see the various cache grease down the right hand side of the page and all published in open formats in CSV, XML, KML and the whole thing was to try and encourage people to reuse, but also you know to bring transparency to the work we were doing.
An encourage collaboration with the city.
It's our finger.
A year later, at the four authorities, local authorities covering the Dublin region got together.
Initiative called uh blinked.

And there's an open data element to this, but the main focus of doubling in the main purpose of the blinked is to act as an innovation network, a data driven innovation network to look at, solving the problems that the city region faces.
So things around transport around energy around water supply.

And if we could get the data out there as the basis of either building services or as baseline for how you could experiment in the urban environment and trial solutions and see whether they've made a difference.
And on that website doubling study there are now over 250 datasets in the data store, not all in open formats, because sometimes that wasn't possible.
But in this particular case it was more important to get the data out there so that people could look at it and start to innovation started.
Operate, not only did we release data from the four Dublin authorities, but in the absence of an old website per say, we facilitated the publication of data by other national agencies.
So there are 13 organisations at the moment.
Publishing data through this website.
But because innovation is the basis of the Dublin project, we need to see to enable different actors to get together.
So we're talking about businesses were talking about the public sector, the people who own the data.
And we're also talking about third level institutions.

So we run a series of events and we run events on different topics and get the people together, getting them, having conversations, encouraging them to form these networks, and to look at how they can innovate.
So Ireland as a whole.
There's a picture of Hoth and Dublin Bay in the back.
And then in March of last year the government produced any government strategy and contained within this strategy was three objectives on publishing open data.
So in March of last year it became government policy in Ireland to publish open data.

So now what are public bodies must start to release open date and now that's over the lifespan of this plan, which is a three year lifespan but they have to come up with a plan as to how they will actually start to release this data.
So now it's government policy for open data to be released in Ireland.
So we were delighted when that came about, because it meant that that lead that we had taken was finally bearing through.

National level and then in December of last year, the government announced the commitment Yards government announced that they would a statement of intent that they would join the Open Government Partnership and again that brings with it a commitment to publishing data openly.
So that's the background.
That's where we are in Ireland in terms of the publication of open data, and I want to look at some examples of reuse.
In Ireland, so one of the things when we got started with the update, so we obviously wanted to be reused.
But when we created the site it was a bit like the Field of Dreams.
Build it and they will come and we built it and they didn't come source in there.
And we say OK, why is nobody using this data?
So we decided to incentivize the reuse of the data and we run this competition.
We got sponsorship from local businesses 11 and a half thousand Euro prize money and we ran a we had prize categories on things that were important to us in the Council community enterprises.
Tourism and as a result of that competition.
22 apps that was under conditions they had to be working apps and they had to be available free of charge for six months after competition.
22 apps.
Created that.
It's part of the website.
If you wanted dated or finger dot IE you will see the various details.
That's the the overall winner of the comp.
Station and there's the various category winners I think is Fatty and there he is.

And just discover finger is the app that was created by the winning entrance and this is effectively a tour guide to Heritage Property Heritage Properties in the Fingal area and the wider Dublin area with gamification approach in a rewards based approach.
If you visit three properties you then get a free Cup of tea at another property.
What's interesting about this is that the individual concerned built this on top of a platform for creating tour guides and he's been through an incentive program or a startup program an.
Initiative with the National Digital Research Center here in Ireland to develop, so he's looking to develop the platform on which this app was based.
Further, as a commercial offering.
Again, one of the category winners was another one called My Pee Pee.
This is my planning permission or are building permits affectively so because the four Dublin authorities had released this data.
This guy, Kieron Gillen, was able to build this web service where you could look at all the planning applications.
Now what you have to do up to now to achieve this was to visit each local authorities website separately and there was a demand there from people.
Why can't you just go to one place to see all of this data?
Why can't we get notifications?
So this guy, this company built a service to do this and has since gone on and contacted a total of 20 local authorities out of the 34 in the country and got that data from them.
This is Mantis is now looking at at marketing this both in the UK and the US.
So the Irish market doesn't see is big enough for this.
Again he has been through the start of program in the DND RC, but there's a win win here because we didn't have to pay for this to be developed.
We didn't have to spend public money on making this service available and here is a guy making a, you know, building a business on top of this day.
Hit the road or another example there in our startup dash.
Well again they would same program.
They were one of the first ones to start using public sector data and it's a public transport journey planner that they produce.
And again, a recent one currently going through the same starter program, and it's interesting that in all these ones they've been through this digital startup accelerator program.
They are currently in there looking at developing this iPhone app about how to find and pay for parking in an urban area, and again they be looking to market that outside of our end as well.

So there are examples of how people have reused today, so here's an example of how a website that was created and this is like fix my street or open 311 from the states where you can report fault in local authority area.
So problems with roads or problems with water supply or graffiti etc etc.
The important thing about this service which was built by local government is that there's an open API.
It's built on the shady open source platform, but the API behind it is open and that his men.
And that another commercial company who have an offering called rate my area were able to build their version to complement what they're offering.
Called fixed my area.
And not only that, another actually a voluntary organization who also run careers.com created fixed my street based on the UK open source data for the same one.
All of them using the same API.
So the data is been fed in through the open API and this choice there about which platform people decide is best for them to use.
The Irish Open data community has become very active recently, particularly since November of last year, and didn't.
I would attend most of the meetings and there's a comment here engineered, and they make their premises available to us next Thursday.
Week is the next meet up and it's going to be on the subject of I can't remember what the subject in the next meeting is going to be.
Actually, it's the commercial reuse of data.
The last one was on.
What was it that was unhealthy?
I think, but effectively this community that resided online for two years came into the real world in November of last year and the next meet up is going to be 6 meters.
So those that community of people starting to get together and talk about and discuss how to reuse the data and particularly the health data issue, is one that they are discussing a lot.
At the moment I'm trying to see can get help data in Ireland released.
And as part of International Open Day today in February, the community organized a hackathon and 10 different projects.
Here were being worked up again.
You can see the two of those around health and they're being pursued.
So that's a very quick run through of the state of augmentation Ireland and the reuse examples, and you'll find that their slide deck on slide share, so thank you very much.
